Continuous Claude: The Ultimate Context Management System for Claude Code

Dec 25, 2025
Vibe Sparking

Continuous Claude: The Ultimate Context Management System for Claude Code

Section titled “Continuous Claude: The Ultimate Context Management System for Claude Code”

When working with Claude Code on complex projects, you’ve likely encountered the frustrating “context degradation” problem. After several compaction cycles, you’re essentially working with a summary of a summary of a summary. Signal degrades into noise, and Claude starts hallucinating context.

Continuous Claude solves this fundamental problem through a revolutionary approach: clear, don’t compact.

The Core Problem: Context Compaction Decay

Section titled “The Core Problem: Context Compaction Decay”

Traditional approaches try to optimize compaction algorithms. Continuous Claude takes a fundamentally different path: preserve state externally, clear context completely, resume with full signal.

The Solution: Ledgers and Handoffs

Section titled “The Solution: Ledgers and Handoffs”

Why This Works

Section titled “Why This Works”
  • Ledgers are lossless - You control exactly what’s saved
  • Fresh context = full signal - No degraded summaries
  • Agents spawn clean - Each agent gets isolated context windows

Key Features

Section titled “Key Features”

1. Continuity System

Section titled “1. Continuity System”

Within-Session (Ledger)

Before running /clear:

Creates/updates CONTINUITY_CLAUDE-<session>.md with:

  • Goal and constraints
  • What’s done, what’s next
  • Key decisions
  • Working files

Between-Sessions (Handoff)

When done for the day:

Creates detailed handoff with:

  • Complete context
  • Recent changes with file:line references
  • Learnings and patterns
  • Next steps

2. Hook System Architecture

Section titled “2. Hook System Architecture”

Continuous Claude uses a sophisticated hook system that intercepts Claude Code lifecycle events:

EventWhenWhat It Does
SessionStartNew session, /clear, compactLoads ledger + latest handoff into context
PreCompactBefore context compactionCreates auto-handoff, blocks manual compact
UserPromptSubmitBefore processing user messageShows skill suggestions, context warnings
PostToolUseAfter Edit/Write/BashTracks modified files for auto-summary
SubagentStopAgent finishesLogs agent completion
SessionEndSession closesCleanup temp files

3. MCP Code Execution Without Context Pollution

Section titled “3. MCP Code Execution Without Context Pollution”

Tools are executed via scripts, not loaded into context. This saves significant tokens:

4. Agent Orchestration

Section titled “4. Agent Orchestration”

For complex implementations, the implement_plan orchestrator spawns task agents:

Each task agent:

  1. Reads previous handoff
  2. Does its work with TDD
  3. Creates handoff for next agent
  4. Returns summary to orchestrator

Quick Start

Section titled “Quick Start”

Option 1: Use in a Single Project

Section titled “Option 1: Use in a Single Project”

Option 2: Install Globally

Section titled “Option 2: Install Globally”

Option 3: Initialize a New Project

Section titled “Option 3: Initialize a New Project”

Natural Language Triggers

Section titled “Natural Language Triggers”

Continuous Claude responds to natural language. Say certain phrases and Claude activates the right skill or spawns an agent.

Session Management

Section titled “Session Management”
Say ThisWhat Happens
”save state”, “update ledger”, “before clear”Updates continuity ledger
”done for today”, “wrap up”, “create handoff”Creates detailed handoff doc
”resume work”, “continue from handoff”Loads handoff, continues

Planning & Implementation

Section titled “Planning & Implementation”
Say ThisWhat Happens
”create plan”, “design”, “architect”Spawns plan-agent
”validate plan”, “before implementing”Spawns validate-agent
”implement plan”, “execute plan”Spawns implement_plan

Code Quality

Section titled “Code Quality”
Say ThisWhat Happens
”implement”, “add feature”, “fix bug”TDD workflow activates
”lint”, “code quality”, “auto-fix”Runs qlty-check
”commit”, “push”, “save changes”Runs commit skill

StatusLine: Real-Time Context Indicator

Section titled “StatusLine: Real-Time Context Indicator”

The colored status bar shows context usage:

Color coding:

  • 🟢 Green (< 60%): Normal
  • 🟡 Yellow (60-79%): Warning - consider handoff soon
  • 🔴 Red (≥ 80%): Critical - create handoff now

Skills vs Agents

Section titled “Skills vs Agents”

Skills run in current context - quick, focused, minimal token overhead.

Agents spawn with fresh context - use for complex tasks that would degrade in compacted context.

When to Use Agents

Section titled “When to Use Agents”
  • Brownfield exploration → rp-explorer
  • Multi-step research → research-agent
  • Complex debugging → debug-agent
  • Implementation with handoffs → implement_plan

Optional Integrations

Section titled “Optional Integrations”

Braintrust Session Tracing

Section titled “Braintrust Session Tracing”

Track every session for learning from past work:

  1. Session traces - Every turn, tool call, and LLM response logged
  2. Automatic learnings - Extracts “What Worked/Failed/Patterns” at session end
  3. Artifact Index integration - Handoffs linked to trace IDs

Compound Learnings

Section titled “Compound Learnings”

Transform session learnings into permanent rules:

Directory Structure

Section titled “Directory Structure”

Comparison: Traditional vs Continuous Claude

Section titled “Comparison: Traditional vs Continuous Claude”
AspectTraditional ApproachContinuous Claude
Context DegradationCumulative lossZero loss
Session ContinuityManual notesAutomated ledgers
Agent ContextInherited degradedFresh isolated
Learning LoopNoneCompound learnings
Token EfficiencyTools loaded in contextScripts executed externally

Best Practices

Section titled “Best Practices”
  1. Update ledger before /clear - Always save state first
  2. Create handoffs at stopping points - Don’t wait until context is critical
  3. Use agents for complex tasks - They get clean context
  4. Leverage compound learnings - Turn patterns into rules
  5. Watch the StatusLine - It shows when to create handoffs

Conclusion

Section titled “Conclusion”

Continuous Claude represents a paradigm shift in how we approach context management for AI coding assistants. By embracing “clear, don’t compact” and building robust state preservation through ledgers and handoffs, it enables:

  • Lossless context preservation across sessions
  • Token-efficient MCP execution without context pollution
  • Intelligent agent orchestration with isolated context windows
  • Continuous learning that improves over time

For teams working on complex, long-running projects with Claude Code, Continuous Claude is an essential addition to your development toolkit.

References

Section titled “References”
  • Continuous Claude GitHub Repository
  • Anthropic MCP Documentation
  • Braintrust Claude Plugin

  • Claude Code

  • MCP

Using Google Antigravity to Fix App Store Review Issues: A Real-World Case Study

Dec 25, 2025
Vibe Sparking

Using Google Antigravity to Fix App Store Review Issues: A Real-World Case Study

Section titled “Using Google Antigravity to Fix App Store Review Issues: A Real-World Case Study”

“Deploy agents that autonomously plan, execute, and verify complex tasks across your editor, terminal, and browser.” — Google Antigravity, the agent-first IDE that transforms how we solve development problems.

App Store rejections are every iOS developer’s nightmare. When Apple sends that dreaded email about “issues with your submission,” the clock starts ticking. But what if you had an AI-powered development platform that could help you identify, understand, and fix these issues in minutes instead of hours?

Enter Google Antigravity — Google’s revolutionary agent-first IDE that’s changing the game for developers worldwide.

What is Google Antigravity?

Section titled “What is Google Antigravity?”

Google Antigravity is an AI-powered integrated development environment (IDE) announced on November 18, 2025, alongside Gemini 3. Unlike traditional IDEs with AI assistants bolted on, Antigravity is built from the ground up with an agent-first architecture.

Key Features

Section titled “Key Features”
FeatureDescription
Editor ViewFamiliar IDE experience with AI-powered tab completion and inline commands
Manager ViewControl center for orchestrating multiple agents working in parallel
Multi-Tool ExecutionAgents access editor, terminal, and browser autonomously
Artifact GenerationVisual verification through task lists, plans, and screenshots
Multi-Model SupportGemini 3 Pro, Claude Sonnet 4.5, GPT-OSS-120B

The platform is available free during public preview for macOS, Windows, and Linux at antigravity.google/download.

The Real-World Scenario: MoneyMind App Rejection

Section titled “The Real-World Scenario: MoneyMind App Rejection”

Let me walk you through a real case study of how I used Google Antigravity to fix an App Store rejection for the MoneyMind (省钱思维) iOS app.

Step 1: Receiving the Rejection Notice

Breaking: Google Finally Lets You Change Your @gmail.com Address

Dec 25, 2025
Vibe Sparking

The Long-Awaited Feature Is Here

Section titled “The Long-Awaited Feature Is Here”

For years, Gmail users have been stuck with whatever email address they created—even if it was something embarrassing from their teenage years. That’s finally changing. Google is gradually rolling out the ability to change your @gmail.com address to a new @gmail.com address, and this is huge news for anyone who’s ever regretted their email username choice.

What’s New?

Section titled “What’s New?”

According to Google’s official support page, you can now:

  • Change your Gmail address from one @gmail.com to another @gmail.com
  • Keep all your data - photos, messages, emails, everything stays intact
  • Use both addresses - your old address becomes an alias that still receives emails
  • Sign in with either - both old and new addresses work for login

How It Works

Section titled “How It Works”

Key Features

Section titled “Key Features”
FeatureDetails
Old Address HandlingBecomes a backup/alias address
Email ReceptionBoth addresses receive emails to same inbox
Data MigrationNo data loss - everything is preserved
Sign-in OptionsCan use either old or new address
OwnershipOld address remains yours permanently

Important Limitations

Section titled “Important Limitations”

Before you rush to change your address, here are the limitations:

  1. Maximum 3 new addresses: You can create up to 3 new Gmail addresses, giving your account a total of 4 addresses maximum
  2. 12-month cooldown: After changing, you can’t create a new Gmail address for 12 months
  3. Cannot delete new address: For 12 months after changing, you cannot delete your new address
  4. Old address stays: Your old address cannot be completely removed—it remains as a backup address
  5. No one else can use it: Your old address is permanently reserved for you

Step-by-Step Guide

Section titled “Step-by-Step Guide”

Step 1: Check If You Have Access

Section titled “Step 1: Check If You Have Access”

The feature is gradually rolling out, so not everyone has it yet. To check:

  1. Go to myaccount.google.com/google-account-email
  2. Sign in if prompted
  3. Click Personal info in the left navigation
  4. Click Email → Google Account email
  5. Look for “Change Google Account email” option
    • If you see it: You have access! Continue to Step 2
    • If you don’t see it: The feature isn’t available to you yet

Step 2: Review Potential Issues

Section titled “Step 2: Review Potential Issues”

Before changing, consider these scenarios:

  • Chromebook users: May need additional steps
  • “Sign in with Google” on third-party sites: Some sites may require re-authentication
  • Chrome Remote Desktop: Remote connections may need to be re-established
  • App settings: Some app settings may reset (similar to logging in on a new device)

Pro tip: Back up your important data before making the change!

Step 3: Make the Change

Section titled “Step 3: Make the Change”
  1. Enter your desired new username
  2. The username must be unique (not used by another Google account)
  3. Click Change email → Yes, change
  4. Follow the on-screen instructions

Once complete, your new email becomes your primary Google Account email, and your old one becomes a backup address.

Frequently Asked Questions

Section titled “Frequently Asked Questions”

Can I switch back to my old address?

Section titled “Can I switch back to my old address?”

Yes! Your original address becomes a backup address. You can switch back anytime by:

  1. Go to myaccount.google.com
  2. Select Email → Google Account email
  3. Find your old address and select “Make this your Google Account email”

Will I lose any emails?

Section titled “Will I lose any emails?”

No. All data is preserved, including emails sent to your old address. Both addresses deliver to the same inbox.

Can I add/remove dots in my Gmail address?

Section titled “Can I add/remove dots in my Gmail address?”

Dots in Gmail are already ignored (john.doe@gmail.com = johndoe@gmail.com). However, you cannot change punctuation in your Google Account email name—if your email contains dots, they will continue to display.

What happens to calendar events I created?

Section titled “What happens to calendar events I created?”

Pre-existing activities (like calendar events) will still show your old email address. The change is not retroactive for historical data.

Can someone else claim my old address?

Section titled “Can someone else claim my old address?”

No. Your old address is permanently reserved for you. Even if you delete your Google account, no one else can use that address.

When Can You Get It?

Section titled “When Can You Get It?”

Google states the feature is “gradually rolling out to all users.” Based on reports from 9to5Google, the feature documentation first appeared in Hindi and is expanding to other regions. If you don’t have access yet, check back periodically.

Best Practices

Section titled “Best Practices”

Before Changing

Section titled “Before Changing”
  1. Document third-party logins: Note which sites use “Sign in with Google”
  2. Export your data: Use Google Takeout to backup
  3. Notify contacts: Let important contacts know about your address change
  4. Update recovery options: Ensure your phone number and recovery email are current

After Changing

Section titled “After Changing”
  1. Test both addresses: Send test emails to both old and new
  2. Re-authenticate apps: Some apps may need you to sign in again
  3. Update professional profiles: LinkedIn, GitHub, etc.
  4. Monitor for issues: Watch for any sign-in or service problems

Who Should (and Shouldn’t) Change

Section titled “Who Should (and Shouldn’t) Change”

Good Candidates

Section titled “Good Candidates”
  • Those with embarrassing or unprofessional email addresses
  • Users who changed their name (marriage, etc.)
  • People wanting a cleaner, more memorable address

Think Twice If

Section titled “Think Twice If”
  • Your current address works fine for your needs
  • You have extensive “Sign in with Google” integrations
  • You’re heavily using Chromebook or Chrome Remote Desktop

The Bottom Line

Section titled “The Bottom Line”

This is a game-changing feature that Gmail users have wanted for over 20 years. While there are limitations (only 3 changes, 12-month cooldowns), the ability to finally update that cringe-worthy email address from 2005 is a welcome addition.

Key takeaway: The feature is rolling out gradually. Check your Google Account settings periodically, and when you see the option, consider carefully whether a change makes sense for your situation.

References

Section titled “References”

  • 9to5Google - Google says it is ‘gradually rolling out’ option to change your @gmail.com address
  • Android Authority - You may finally be able to change your old, embarrassing Gmail address

MCP Defender: Docker's New AI Agent Security Shield

Dec 25, 2025
Vibe Sparking

Docker Acquires MCP Defender: The Security Layer AI Agents Have Been Missing

As AI agents become increasingly autonomous in our development workflows, the security landscape has fundamentally shifted. Enter MCP Defender—a desktop app that Docker recently acquired to protect AI applications like Cursor, Claude Desktop, VS Code, and Windsurf from a growing array of attacks.

1. What is MCP Defender?

Section titled “1. What is MCP Defender?”

MCP Defender is a desktop application that acts as a security proxy for the Model Context Protocol (MCP). Here’s how it works:

  • 🛡️ Automatic Protection: All MCP tool call requests and responses from AI apps are automatically proxied through MCP Defender
  • 🔎 Signature-Based Detection: Intercepted data is checked against a set of security signatures
  • 🔐 User-Controlled Blocking: When harmful content is detected, MCP Defender alerts you and asks whether to allow or block the tool call

Supported AI Apps:

  • Cursor
  • Claude Desktop
  • Visual Studio Code
  • Windsurf

2. Why Docker Acquired MCP Defender

Section titled “2. Why Docker Acquired MCP Defender”

On September 5, 2025, Docker announced the acquisition of MCP Defender, marking a strategic move into AI agent security. The rationale is clear:

“AI agents are getting smarter—and more autonomous. That means new risks, new attack surfaces, and a need for runtime security that moves as fast as dev teams do.”

The Security Gap

Section titled “The Security Gap”

Traditional security tools weren’t designed for AI agents. When an AI agent has the ability to:

  • Execute code
  • Access file systems
  • Make API calls
  • Interact with external services

…the attack surface expands dramatically. MCP Defender fills this critical gap by providing:

CapabilityDescription
Runtime MonitoringContinuous observation of AI agent behavior
Policy EnforcementCustomizable security rules for AI operations
Real-time Threat DetectionIdentifies malicious patterns as they occur
Multi-Client ProtectionSecures multiple AI apps simultaneously

3. Getting Started

Section titled “3. Getting Started”

Quick Install (Mac)

Section titled “Quick Install (Mac)”

Download the latest release directly:

  • Download MCP Defender for Mac

From Source

Section titled “From Source”

Once running, MCP Defender automatically intercepts MCP traffic from supported AI apps—no additional configuration needed.

4. How It Protects You

Section titled “4. How It Protects You”

MCP Defender guards against several attack vectors:

🔴 Prompt Injection Attacks

Section titled “🔴 Prompt Injection Attacks”

Malicious instructions embedded in data that trick AI agents into executing harmful commands.

🔴 Data Exfiltration

Section titled “🔴 Data Exfiltration”

Prevents unauthorized data extraction through AI tool calls.

🔴 Unauthorized Tool Execution

Section titled “🔴 Unauthorized Tool Execution”

Blocks attempts to execute tools or commands beyond the intended scope.

🔴 Supply Chain Attacks

Section titled “🔴 Supply Chain Attacks”

Detects compromised MCP servers or malicious tool definitions.

5. Docker’s Security Vision

Section titled “5. Docker’s Security Vision”

The acquisition fits into Docker’s broader “secure-by-default AI infrastructure” vision:

  • Docker Scout: Container image vulnerability scanning
  • Docker Hardened Images: Pre-secured base images
  • Docker MCP Gateway: Secure MCP server hosting
  • MCP Defender: Runtime AI agent protection

Together, these tools aim to defend the entire AI software supply chain while reducing the security burden on development teams.

6. Real-World Demo

Section titled “6. Real-World Demo”

MCP Defender has demonstrated its value against real attack scenarios:

Attack TypeHow MCP Defender Responds
WhatsApp Data ExfiltrationBlocks unauthorized access to messaging data

The app shows a clear alert dialog when threats are detected, giving you full control over whether to allow or block the action.

7. Final Thoughts

Section titled “7. Final Thoughts”

AI agents are transforming how we build software, but with great power comes great responsibility—and greater attack surfaces. MCP Defender represents a crucial evolution in AI security:

  • For Individual Developers: Peace of mind when using AI coding assistants
  • For Enterprise Teams: Compliance-ready AI agent governance
  • For the Ecosystem: A foundation for secure agentic AI infrastructure

With Docker’s backing, MCP Defender is positioned to become the standard for AI agent security. If you’re using Cursor, Claude Desktop, VS Code, or Windsurf, installing MCP Defender is now a no-brainer.

Quick Verification Beats Documentation: Making Codebases Agent-Ready

Dec 25, 2025
Vibe Sparking

Traditional software development relies on human developers to manually handle ambiguity and implicit knowledge. But AI agents are fundamentally different—they’re highly sensitive to noise and require fast, explicit, and predictable feedback loops. If your codebase lacks rigorous verification mechanisms, agents will inevitably fail in production environments.

This insight fundamentally reshapes how we should prepare our codebases for the AI-assisted development era.

The Core Insight: Tests Over Documentation

Section titled “The Core Insight: Tests Over Documentation”

Simon Willison, a respected voice in the developer community, makes a counterintuitive observation:

“I actually don’t think documentation is too important: LLMs can read the code a lot faster than you to figure out how to use it.”

This challenges the conventional wisdom that comprehensive documentation is the key to maintainable codebases. For AI agents, the calculus is different:

AspectDocumentationAutomated Tests
Feedback SpeedNone (passive reference)Immediate (active validation)
AmbiguityHigh (natural language)Low (pass/fail)
Implicit KnowledgeOften omittedEncoded in assertions
Agent UtilityCan be read, but not verifiedCan be executed and learned from

Why AI Agents Need Quick Verification

Section titled “Why AI Agents Need Quick Verification”

1. Agents Are Noise-Sensitive

Section titled “1. Agents Are Noise-Sensitive”

Unlike human developers who can filter through ambiguous instructions using context and experience, AI agents struggle with:

  • Implicit assumptions buried in code comments
  • Outdated documentation that conflicts with current behavior
  • Edge cases that aren’t mentioned anywhere

Quick verification through tests provides ground truth that agents can trust.

2. Feedback Loops Define Agent Quality

Section titled “2. Feedback Loops Define Agent Quality”

Spotify’s engineering team has extensively studied this in their background coding agents system. Their key finding:

“The verification loop allows the agent and its underlying LLM to gradually confirm it is on the right track before committing to a change.”

Their verification architecture includes:

  • Deterministic Verifiers: Automatically activated based on codebase contents (e.g., Maven verifier for pom.xml files)
  • LLM as Judge: Evaluates proposed changes against original prompts, vetoing ~25% of agent sessions
  • Course Correction: ~50% of vetoed attempts are successfully corrected by agents

3. The “Vibe Coding” Problem

Section titled “3. The “Vibe Coding” Problem”

Research from Augment Code defines “vibe coding” as accepting AI-generated code based on surface-level correctness without systematic validation. This approach:

  • Introduces security vulnerabilities in 45% of cases (according to Veracode)
  • Creates code that handles happy paths perfectly while missing error conditions
  • Leads to identical anti-patterns propagating across services

Practical Framework: 7 Validation Pillars

Section titled “Practical Framework: 7 Validation Pillars”

Based on industry research, here’s a comprehensive framework for making codebases agent-ready:

1. Test-Driven Agent Development (TDAD)

Section titled “1. Test-Driven Agent Development (TDAD)”

Write tests first, then let agents generate implementations:

Simon Willison’s approach: “One of my projects has 1500 tests and Claude Code is really good at selectively executing just tests relevant to the change it is making.”

2. Rich Error Messages

Section titled “2. Rich Error Messages”

This is a low-cost, high-impact improvement:

“If a manual or automated test fails, the more information you can return back to the model the better.”

Instead of:

Provide:

3. Developer Tools as Feedback Channels

Section titled “3. Developer Tools as Feedback Channels”

Configure your codebase with:

  • Linters (ESLint, Ruff, Clippy)
  • Type Checkers (TypeScript, mypy, Pyright)
  • Auto-formatters (Prettier, Black, rustfmt)

“Give coding agents helpful tools to run and they’ll use them.”

4. CI/CD Pipeline Gates

Section titled “4. CI/CD Pipeline Gates”

Implement automated validation stages:

  • Static Analysis (SAST)
  • Dynamic Testing (DAST)
  • Policy Enforcement
  • Compliance Validation

5. Observability Systems

Section titled “5. Observability Systems”

Track agent performance metrics:

  • Code quality telemetry
  • Compilation success rates
  • Test pass rates over time
  • Production behavior monitoring

6. Human Code Review (Still Essential)

Section titled “6. Human Code Review (Still Essential)”

AI frequently generates patterns with subtle integration flaws. Human reviewers catch:

  • Architectural inconsistencies
  • Security anti-patterns
  • Context-specific problems

7. Compound Learning

Section titled “7. Compound Learning”

The most advanced approach: create a learning system, not just an automation pipeline:

“Each bug, test failure, and design insight gets documented and reused by future agents, so every feature makes the next one easier to build.”

The Augmented Coding Model

Section titled “The Augmented Coding Model”

The contrast between “vibe coding” and “augmented coding” comes down to two factors:

FactorVibe CodingAugmented Coding
Feedback LoopLongerShorter
Specification LevelHigh-level, vagueDetailed, precise

For large, complex codebases, augmented coding is essential:

“You can’t simply vibe-code your way through a large and complex codebase. With augmented coding, the AI agent tackles small, clearly-defined tasks with frequent feedback loops.”

Practical Recommendations

Section titled “Practical Recommendations”

For Individual Developers

Section titled “For Individual Developers”
  1. Write tests before handing work to agents
  2. Configure comprehensive linting and type checking
  3. Provide detailed error messages in assertions
  4. Set up local dev server instructions for agents to validate UI changes

For Teams

Section titled “For Teams”
  1. Implement CI/CD gates that catch agent-generated issues
  2. Create AGENTS.md (similar to README.md) for project-specific AI guidance
  3. Document architectural decisions that aren’t obvious from code
  4. Track agent performance metrics over time

For Organizations

Section titled “For Organizations”
  1. Adopt Test-Driven Agent Development (TDAD) as a standard practice
  2. Invest in observability for agent-generated code
  3. Maintain human review requirements for production deployments
  4. Build compound learning systems that improve over time

Key Takeaways

Section titled “Key Takeaways”
  1. Tests > Documentation for AI agents—they provide executable, unambiguous feedback
  2. Quick feedback loops are essential—agents need immediate validation
  3. Rich error messages are a low-cost, high-impact improvement
  4. “Vibe coding” is dangerous in enterprise environments—systematic validation is required
  5. The best practices for humans still apply—agents benefit from well-maintained codebases

The future of AI-assisted development isn’t about replacing human judgment—it’s about creating feedback-rich environments where agents can iterate quickly and humans can focus on architectural decisions and creative problem-solving.

References

Section titled “References”
  • Setting up a codebase for working with coding agents - Simon Willison
  • Background Coding Agents: Predictable Results Through Feedback Loops - Spotify Engineering
  • AI Agent Quality: 7 Frameworks to Go Beyond Vibe Coding - Augment Code
  • Coding for the Future Agentic World - Addy Osmani

Google's 68-Page Prompt Engineering Whitepaper: 10 Best Practices That Actually Work

Dec 25, 2025
Vibe Sparking

Google recently released a 68-page whitepaper on prompt engineering authored by Lee Boonstra, and it’s already being called “the best structured, most readable, and most example-rich guide to LLM prompting as of 2025.” Here are the 10 best practices distilled from this comprehensive guide.

Why This Whitepaper Matters

Section titled “Why This Whitepaper Matters”

LLMs are prediction engines, not reasoning engines. Every word you provide guides the model to predict the next token. Understanding this fundamental principle is the key to mastering prompt engineering.

Techniques may become outdated, but the underlying principles remain constant.

1. Provide Examples, Don’t Just State Requirements

Section titled “1. Provide Examples, Don’t Just State Requirements”

Few-shot prompting consistently outperforms zero-shot approaches. When you provide 3-5 examples, the model understands your expectations far better than any amount of explanation.

Why it works: Examples let the model capture the structure, tone, and format you want. Instead of explaining what “professional” means, show a professional response.

Example:

2. Keep It Simple

Section titled “2. Keep It Simple”

Use action verbs. Avoid obscure expressions. One clear sentence beats three vague paragraphs.

LLMs don’t need pleasantries or context padding. They need direct instructions.

Preferred verbs:

  • Analyze
  • Create
  • Generate
  • Identify
  • Summarize
  • Compare
  • Extract

Before: “I was hoping you could perhaps help me write something that might be useful for understanding the topic of machine learning, if that’s not too much trouble.”

After: “Summarize machine learning in 3 sentences for a non-technical audience.”

3. Specify Output Format Explicitly

Section titled “3. Specify Output Format Explicitly”

Vague instructions produce random results. If you want JSON, say JSON. If you want 500 words, say 500 words.

The more specific your format requirements, the more predictable your outputs.

Weak: “Generate a blog post about video game consoles.”

Strong: “Generate a 3-paragraph blog post about the history of video game consoles. Use conversational style. Each paragraph should be 4-6 sentences. Include one specific statistic per paragraph.”

Pro tip: Request JSON format for structured, processable responses that naturally limit hallucinations:

4. Use Instructions, Not Constraints

Section titled “4. Use Instructions, Not Constraints”

Tell the model what TO DO, not what NOT to do.

Negation is inherently ambiguous for language models. “Don’t be verbose” is less effective than “Limit response to 100 words.”

Avoid ThisDo This Instead
”Don’t list video game names""Only discuss the console, company, year, and sales figures"
"Don’t be wordy""Limit each paragraph to 3 sentences"
"Don’t make things up""If uncertain, respond with ‘I cannot verify this’”

The psychology: Models process positive instructions more reliably because they define a clear action space rather than an infinite exclusion zone.

5. Control Token Length

Section titled “5. Control Token Length”

Cost scales linearly with tokens. Generating 1000 words costs 10x more than generating 100 words.

Always set explicit length constraints when token efficiency matters.

Techniques:

  • “Limit output to 80 characters”
  • “Explain in a tweet-length message”
  • “Respond in exactly 3 bullet points”
  • “Maximum 50 tokens”

Bonus: Token limits also force conciseness, often improving output quality.

6. Use Variables for Reusable Templates

Section titled “6. Use Variables for Reusable Templates”

Extract changeable elements into variables. One well-crafted template can be reused hundreds of times.

Benefits:

  • Consistency across multiple queries
  • Easier A/B testing
  • Programmatic prompt generation
  • Version control friendly

7. Experiment With Different Input Formats

Section titled “7. Experiment With Different Input Formats”

Questions, statements, and instructions produce different results from identical content.

Test multiple approaches:

  • Question: “What are the benefits of exercise?”
  • Statement: “Exercise has multiple benefits. Explain them.”
  • Instruction: “List 5 benefits of regular exercise with scientific backing.”
  • Role-based: “As a fitness coach, explain why clients should exercise.”

Finding: Lists, paragraphs, and dialogue formats also yield varying stability. Find what works best for your use case.

8. Mix Examples in Classification Tasks

Section titled “8. Mix Examples in Classification Tasks”

Don’t cluster all positive examples together. Randomize example order to force pattern learning, not sequence memorization.

Weak (grouped):

Strong (mixed):

Why: Models learn discriminating features when forced to distinguish between adjacent examples of different classes.

9. Adapt to Model Updates

Section titled “9. Adapt to Model Updates”

GPT-4 to GPT-4.5, Gemini 1.0 to 2.0 - prompts need recalibration.

Each model generation has different strengths, quirks, and optimal configurations. What worked yesterday may underperform today.

Best practices:

  • Re-test core prompts with each model update
  • Monitor output quality metrics over time
  • Maintain a prompt changelog
  • Keep baseline examples for comparison

Reality check: Continuous prompt optimization is not optional maintenance - it’s core product work.

10. Document Every Attempt

Section titled “10. Document Every Attempt”

Use a table to track: model, temperature, prompt, output. Three days later, you won’t remember which version worked best.

Recommended tracking fields:

FieldPurpose
ModelWhich model version
TemperatureRandomness setting
PromptExact prompt used
OutputResult received
Quality1-5 rating
NotesWhat worked/didn’t

For RAG systems: Also document which factors influenced content insertion - queries, chunking settings, and chunk outputs.

Bonus: Chain of Thought (CoT) Best Practices

Section titled “Bonus: Chain of Thought (CoT) Best Practices”

For complex reasoning tasks, set temperature to 0 for rigorous, single-answer problems requiring strict logical reasoning.

Self-Consistency Prompting: Send the same Chain-of-Thought prompt multiple times at high temperature, then “vote” on the most common final answer. This makes answers more robust and reduces hallucinations.

Step-Back Prompting: Instead of solving directly, first prompt the model to consider general principles or patterns, then use that response to guide the specific task.

The Core Insight

Section titled “The Core Insight”

All 10 practices share the same underlying logic:

LLMs are prediction engines, not reasoning engines. Every word you provide guides token prediction. Specificity reduces ambiguity. Examples outperform explanations. Positive instructions beat negative constraints.

Techniques evolve. Principles persist.

Resources

Section titled “Resources”
  • Google Prompt Engineering Whitepaper on Kaggle
  • Author: Lee Boonstra

What’s your most effective prompt engineering technique? The best prompts often come from systematic experimentation and rigorous documentation.

  • Prompt Engineering

OpenSkills: Universal Skills Loader for AI Coding Agents

Dec 24, 2025
Vibe Sparking

OpenSkills: Universal Skills Loader for AI Coding Agents

Section titled “OpenSkills: Universal Skills Loader for AI Coding Agents”

AI coding agents have revolutionized software development, but each agent operates in its own ecosystem with unique capabilities. OpenSkills bridges this gap by bringing Anthropic’s powerful skills system to all AI coding agents.

What is OpenSkills?

Section titled “What is OpenSkills?”

OpenSkills is a universal skills loader that implements Anthropic’s Agent Skills specification for any AI coding agent. It brings Claude Code’s skills system to Cursor, Windsurf, Aider, and other agents with 100% compatibility.

Why OpenSkills Matters

Section titled “Why OpenSkills Matters”

The Problem

Section titled “The Problem”

Each AI coding agent has its own way of handling specialized capabilities:

  • Claude Code has a built-in skills system with marketplace
  • Cursor uses custom rules and instructions
  • Windsurf has its own knowledge management
  • Aider relies on conventions and prompts

This fragmentation means skills and workflows don’t transfer between agents.

The Solution

Section titled “The Solution”

OpenSkills provides a unified skills format that works across all agents:

  • Same prompt format - <available_skills> XML structure
  • Same marketplace - Access Anthropic’s official skills
  • Same folder structure - Uses .claude/skills/ by default
  • Same SKILL.md format - YAML frontmatter + markdown instructions
  • Progressive disclosure - Load skills on demand, not upfront

Key Features

Section titled “Key Features”

1. Universal Compatibility

Section titled “1. Universal Compatibility”

OpenSkills works with any AI coding agent by using CLI commands instead of proprietary tool calls:

AspectClaude CodeOpenSkills
InvocationSkill("pdf")openskills read pdf
Prompt Format<available_skills> XMLIdentical
Folder Structure.claude/skills/Identical
SKILL.md FormatYAML + markdownIdentical

2. Multiple Installation Sources

Section titled “2. Multiple Installation Sources”

Install skills from various sources:

3. Progressive Disclosure

Section titled “3. Progressive Disclosure”

Skills load only when needed, keeping your agent’s context clean and focused. When the agent needs a skill:

  1. Agent scans <available_skills> in AGENTS.md
  2. Agent executes openskills read <skill-name>
  3. Full skill instructions load into context
  4. Agent follows instructions to complete task

4. Bundled Resources Support

Section titled “4. Bundled Resources Support”

  • docx - Document creation with tracked changes
  • pptx - Presentation creation and editing
  • canvas-design - Create posters and visual designs
  • mcp-builder - Build Model Context Protocol servers
  • skill-creator - Guide for authoring skills

Why CLI Instead of MCP?

Section titled “Why CLI Instead of MCP?”

OpenSkills uses CLI commands rather than MCP (Model Context Protocol) because:

  1. Skills are static instructions - Not dynamic tools requiring server connections
  2. No server needed - Skills are just markdown files
  3. Universal compatibility - CLI works with any agent
  4. Follows Anthropic’s design - Skills were designed as SKILL.md files
  5. Simpler for users - No server management required

MCP and skills solve different problems. OpenSkills implements the skills spec as designed.

Best Practices

Section titled “Best Practices”

1. Keep Skills Focused

Section titled “1. Keep Skills Focused”

Each skill should handle one specific domain. Don’t create “do everything” skills.

2. Write Clear Descriptions

Section titled “2. Write Clear Descriptions”

The description helps agents decide when to load the skill:

3. Use Progressive Disclosure

Section titled “3. Use Progressive Disclosure”

Put detailed instructions in SKILL.md, not the description. This keeps the <available_skills> section compact.

4. Include Examples

Section titled “4. Include Examples”

Help agents understand how to use your skill with concrete examples in the instructions.

UniversalYesPer-agentRequires support
Progressive LoadingYesNoYes
Marketplace AccessYesNoDifferent
Setup ComplexityLowVariesHigher
Bundled ResourcesYesLimitedYes

Conclusion

Section titled “Conclusion”

OpenSkills democratizes AI agent skills by making Anthropic’s well-designed skills system available to all agents. Whether you’re using Claude Code, Cursor, Windsurf, or Aider, you can now benefit from:

  • Standardized skills format across agents
  • Access to Anthropic’s marketplace via GitHub
  • Progressive disclosure for clean contexts
  • Easy skill sharing within teams and communities

Personal AI Infrastructure (PAI): Build Your Own AI-Powered Operating System

Dec 24, 2025
Vibe Sparking

Personal AI Infrastructure (PAI): Build Your Own AI-Powered Operating System

Section titled “Personal AI Infrastructure (PAI): Build Your Own AI-Powered Operating System”

Introduction

Section titled “Introduction”

Right now, the most powerful AI setups are being built inside companies for efficiency and profits. But what if you could have the same sophisticated AI infrastructure available to everyone? That’s exactly what Personal AI Infrastructure (PAI) delivers.

Created by security researcher and AI pioneer Daniel Miessler, PAI is an open-source template for building your own AI-powered operating system. It’s the foundation for creating a Personal AI System that understands your larger goals and context, gets better over time, and works for you because it’s yours.

What is PAI?

Section titled “What is PAI?”

PAI (Personal AI Infrastructure) is open-source scaffolding built on Claude Code, designed to be platform-independent. The architecture, skills, and workflows are structured so future migrations to other AI platforms remain straightforward.

Core Philosophy

Section titled “Core Philosophy”

“The best AI in the world should be available to everyone.”

The purpose of technology is to serve humans—not the other way around. PAI enables regular people to use AI to help them flourish, not just tech workers inside corporations.

Core Components

Section titled “Core Components”

1. Skills System

Section titled “1. Skills System”

Skills are self-contained AI capabilities with routing, workflows, and documentation. Each skill follows the “skills-as-containers” pattern:

ComponentDescription
SkillsDomain expertise encoded as reusable modules (security analysis, content creation, research workflows)
AgentsSpecialized AI personalities for different tasks (engineer, researcher, designer)
HooksEvent-driven automation that captures work and manages state
HistoryAutomatic documentation system (UOCS) that captures everything

2. File-System-Based Context

Section titled “2. File-System-Based Context”

Instead of cramming everything into massive prompts, PAI organizes knowledge into a hierarchical structure:

  • Projects: Active work with context
  • Methodologies: How you approach problems
  • Philosophy: Your principles and values
  • Tools: Technical capabilities
  • Tasks: Specific actions and workflows

Each directory contains specialized knowledge loaded only when needed.

3. Native Fabric Patterns

Section titled “3. Native Fabric Patterns”

PAI includes native integration with Fabric patterns—248+ AI patterns for content analysis and generation:

  • extract_wisdom: Extract key insights from content
  • summarize: Create concise summaries
  • threat_modeling: Security analysis workflows
  • And 245+ more patterns

Patterns run directly in Claude’s context using your subscription’s model, with full conversation history access.

The Thirteen Founding Principles

Section titled “The Thirteen Founding Principles”

PAI is built on 13 foundational principles:

  1. Clear Thinking + Prompting is King - Quality outcomes depend on quality thinking
  2. Scaffolding > Model - System architecture matters more than AI model power
  3. As Deterministic as Possible - Same input → Same output
  4. Code Before Prompts - Write code to solve problems, prompts to orchestrate
  5. Spec / Test / Evals First - Define expected behavior before implementation
  6. UNIX Philosophy - Do one thing well, compose tools through standard interfaces
  7. ENG / SRE Principles - Apply software engineering rigor to AI systems
  8. CLI as Interface - Every operation accessible via command line
  9. Goal → Code → CLI → Prompts → Agents - Proper development pipeline
  10. Meta / Self Update System - Systems that improve themselves
  11. Custom Skill Management - Skills as organizational units
  12. Custom History System - Automatic capture of valuable work
  13. Custom Agent Personalities - Specialized agents for different tasks

Section titled “Quick Start Installation”

macOS Setup

Section titled “macOS Setup”

Section titled “Linux Setup”

Section titled “Windows Setup (PowerShell as Admin)”

Best Practices

Section titled “Best Practices”

1. Start Clean, Small, and Simple

Section titled “1. Start Clean, Small, and Simple”

Build the scaffolding that makes AI reliable before adding complexity. Following Miessler’s “solve once, reuse forever” philosophy, each component becomes reusable.

2. Encode Your Domain Expertise

Section titled “2. Encode Your Domain Expertise”

Every time you solve a problem, turn it into a reusable component:

  • Commands for specific workflows (write-blog-post, analyze-security)
  • Fabric patterns for content analysis and generation
  • Skills for domain expertise

3. Let History Compound

Section titled “3. Let History Compound”

The History System solves context loss between sessions. Everything gets automatically documented:

  • Work artifacts and decisions
  • Patterns and approaches used
  • Lessons learned

4. Customize Your Agent Identity

Section titled “4. Customize Your Agent Identity”

PAI is fully platform-agnostic—your AI identity, your system:

  • Configure your DA (Digital Assistant) name
  • Set your preferences and principles
  • Define your working style

  • Threat modeling with domain context

  • Security report generation

  • Learning documentation

  • Observability Dashboard: Real-time agent monitoring with live charts
  • Genericized Identity: Configure your DA name across the entire system
  • Platform-Agnostic Configuration: Clear separation of identity/paths and API keys
  • Native Fabric Patterns: 248 patterns run directly in Claude’s context

FAQ

Section titled “FAQ”

Q: Is PAI just for developers?

Section titled “Q: Is PAI just for developers?”

No! PAI is designed to give regular people access to sophisticated AI infrastructure. While technical knowledge helps, the goal is human flourishing, not just developer productivity.

Q: Can I use PAI with models other than Claude?

Section titled “Q: Can I use PAI with models other than Claude?”

Yes. While currently built on Claude Code, PAI’s architecture is platform-independent. The skills, workflows, and patterns can migrate to other AI platforms.

Q: How does PAI differ from just using Claude Code?

Section titled “Q: How does PAI differ from just using Claude Code?”

PAI adds structure, history, skills, and patterns on top of Claude Code. It’s not a different AI—it’s a framework that makes Claude Code work specifically for you.

Q: Is PAI free?

Section titled “Q: Is PAI free?”

Yes, PAI is open-source under MIT license. You’ll need a Claude subscription for the underlying AI capabilities.

Comparison with Similar Tools

References

Section titled “References”

  • Fabric Framework - AI patterns library

Summary

Section titled “Summary”

Personal AI Infrastructure represents a paradigm shift in how we think about AI assistance. Instead of relying on generic chatbots or corporate AI systems, PAI empowers individuals to build AI infrastructure that:

  • Knows your context: Your goals, preferences, and working style
  • Learns over time: History compounds, patterns emerge
  • Serves your interests: Not engagement metrics or corporate profits
  • Remains yours: Open-source, portable, and customizable

As Daniel Miessler points out, the real power of AI infrastructure lies not in model intelligence but in orchestration. The magic happens when you create a system that knows you, adapts to your needs, and works autonomously on your behalf.

Start clean. Start small. Build the AI infrastructure you need.

SkillsMP: The Open Marketplace for AI Agent Skills

Dec 24, 2025
Vibe Sparking

SkillsMP: The Open Marketplace for AI Agent Skills

Section titled “SkillsMP: The Open Marketplace for AI Agent Skills”

AI coding assistants have become indispensable tools for developers, but their capabilities are often limited to what comes built-in. SkillsMP changes this by providing an open marketplace where developers can discover, install, and share skills across multiple AI platforms.

What is SkillsMP?

Section titled “What is SkillsMP?”

SkillsMP is an open-source marketplace hosting over 31,000 agent skills that work seamlessly with the most popular AI coding assistants:

  • Claude Code - Anthropic’s official CLI tool
  • Codex CLI - OpenAI’s command-line interface
  • ChatGPT - The world’s most popular AI assistant

All skills use the unified SKILL.md format, ensuring compatibility across platforms and making it easy to share capabilities between different AI tools.

The SKILL.md Standard

Section titled “The SKILL.md Standard”

The SKILL.md format is the foundation of the agent skills ecosystem. It defines modular capabilities through:

  • Instructions - Clear guidance for the AI on what the skill does and how to use it
  • Scripts (optional) - Supporting code that extends functionality
  • Templates (optional) - Pre-built structures for common outputs

Key Characteristics

Section titled “Key Characteristics”

Skills are model-invoked, not user-invoked. This means the AI assistant decides when to activate a skill based on the context of your request, rather than requiring explicit commands.

Installation Paths

Section titled “Installation Paths”

Different AI tools have their own skill directories:

ToolPersonal SkillsProject Skills
Claude Code~/.claude/skills/.claude/skills/
Codex CLI~/.codex/skills/.codex/skills/
ChatGPTVia plugin systemVia plugin system

Skill Categories

Section titled “Skill Categories”

SkillsMP organizes its vast library into 13 categories:

  1. Tools - General productivity enhancers
  2. Development - Code generation and refactoring
  3. Data & AI - Data analysis and ML utilities
  4. Business - Business process automation
  5. DevOps - Infrastructure and deployment
  6. Testing & Security - QA and security scanning
  7. Documentation - Docs generation and maintenance
  8. Content & Media - Content creation tools
  9. Lifestyle - Personal productivity
  10. Research - Information gathering
  11. Databases - Database operations
  12. Blockchain - Web3 and crypto tools

Quality Standards

Section titled “Quality Standards”

SkillsMP maintains quality through:

  • Minimum 2-star filter - Only GitHub repos with community validation

  • User review recommended - Always review code before installation

Agent Skills for Context Engineering: Build Production-Grade AI Agent Systems

Dec 24, 2025
Vibe Sparking

Agent Skills for Context Engineering: Build Production-Grade AI Agent Systems

Section titled “Agent Skills for Context Engineering: Build Production-Grade AI Agent Systems”

In the rapidly evolving landscape of AI development, context engineering has emerged as one of the most critical disciplines for building effective agent systems. Unlike prompt engineering, which focuses on crafting effective instructions, context engineering addresses the holistic curation of all information entering a model’s limited attention window.

Agent Skills for Context Engineering by Murat Can Koylan is a comprehensive, open-source collection designed to teach the art and science of curating context to maximize agent effectiveness across any platform.

What is Context Engineering?

Section titled “What is Context Engineering?”

Context engineering is the discipline of managing the language model’s context window. The fundamental challenge is that context windows are constrained not by raw token capacity but by attention mechanics.

The Core Problem

Section titled “The Core Problem”

As context length increases, models exhibit predictable degradation patterns:

  • Lost-in-the-Middle Phenomenon - Information in the middle of long contexts gets less attention
  • U-Shaped Attention Curves - Models focus more on beginning and end of context
  • Attention Scarcity - Limited “attention budget” must be allocated wisely

The Solution

Section titled “The Solution”

Effective context engineering means finding the smallest possible set of high-signal tokens that maximize the likelihood of desired outcomes. This requires understanding what context is, how it degrades, and how to optimize it.

Skills Overview

Section titled “Skills Overview”

The collection is organized into three tiers of increasing complexity.

Foundational Skills

Section titled “Foundational Skills”

These skills establish the foundational understanding required for all subsequent context engineering work.

SkillDescription
context-fundamentalsUnderstand what context is, why it matters, and the anatomy of context in agent systems
context-degradationRecognize patterns of context failure: lost-in-middle, poisoning, distraction, and clash
context-compressionDesign and evaluate compression strategies for long-running sessions

Architectural Skills

Section titled “Architectural Skills”

These skills cover the patterns and structures for building effective agent systems.

SkillDescription
multi-agent-patternsMaster orchestrator, peer-to-peer, and hierarchical multi-agent architectures
memory-systemsDesign short-term, long-term, and graph-based memory architectures
tool-designBuild tools that agents can use effectively

Operational Skills

Section titled “Operational Skills”

These skills address the ongoing operation and optimization of agent systems.

SkillDescription
context-optimizationApply compaction, masking, and caching strategies
evaluationBuild evaluation frameworks for agent systems

Key Concepts Deep Dive

Section titled “Key Concepts Deep Dive”

1. Context Fundamentals

Section titled “1. Context Fundamentals”

Understanding the anatomy of context in agent systems is essential:

Components of Context:

  • System prompts
  • Tool definitions
  • Retrieved documents
  • Message history
  • Tool outputs

Each component competes for limited attention. Effective agents prioritize high-signal information and compress or eliminate low-signal content.

2. Context Degradation Patterns

Section titled “2. Context Degradation Patterns”

Recognizing failure patterns helps prevent them:

Lost-in-Middle: Critical information placed in the middle of long contexts receives less model attention.

Context Poisoning: Bad or conflicting information corrupts the model’s understanding.

Context Distraction: Irrelevant information diverts attention from important content.

Context Clash: Contradictory instructions or data create confusion.

3. Multi-Agent Patterns

Section titled “3. Multi-Agent Patterns”

Three primary architectures for multi-agent systems:

Orchestrator Pattern: A central agent coordinates specialized sub-agents, managing task delegation and result aggregation.

Peer-to-Peer Pattern: Agents communicate directly without central coordination, suitable for collaborative tasks.

Hierarchical Pattern: Layered agent structures where higher-level agents manage groups of lower-level agents.

4. Memory Systems

Section titled “4. Memory Systems”

Effective agents require multiple memory types:

Short-term Memory:

  • Recent conversation context
  • Current task state
  • Immediate working memory

Long-term Memory:

  • Persistent knowledge stores
  • User preferences
  • Historical patterns

Graph-based Memory:

  • Relationship maps between concepts
  • Entity connections
  • Semantic networks

Installation and Usage

Section titled “Installation and Usage”

For Claude Code

Section titled “For Claude Code”

Install skills by referencing the repository or copying skill folders into your configured skills directory:

When working on context engineering tasks, activate relevant skills to load their instructions.

For Cursor

Section titled “For Cursor”

Copy skill content into .cursorrules or create project-specific rules files:

The skills provide the context and guidelines that Cursor’s agent needs for effective context engineering.

For Custom Implementations

Section titled “For Custom Implementations”

Extract the principles and patterns from any skill and implement them in your agent framework. The skills are deliberately platform-agnostic, making them applicable to any LLM-based system.

Recommended Use Scenarios

Section titled “Recommended Use Scenarios”

1. Building Production Agent Systems

Section titled “1. Building Production Agent Systems”

When developing agents for real-world deployment:

  • Start with fundamentals - Understand context anatomy before optimization
  • Design memory early - Memory architecture affects all downstream decisions
  • Plan for degradation - Build in monitoring and recovery mechanisms
  • Test at scale - Evaluation frameworks catch issues before production

2. Optimizing Existing Agents

Section titled “2. Optimizing Existing Agents”

For teams with existing agent systems:

  • Diagnose context issues - Use degradation patterns to identify problems
  • Apply compression strategies - Reduce token usage without losing signal
  • Implement caching - Avoid redundant context loading
  • Add instrumentation - Build visibility into context usage

3. Multi-Agent Architecture Design

Section titled “3. Multi-Agent Architecture Design”

When building systems with multiple coordinating agents:

  • Choose the right pattern - Orchestrator vs peer-to-peer vs hierarchical
  • Design communication protocols - How agents share context
  • Manage shared memory - Coordination without conflicts
  • Handle failures gracefully - Recovery when agents fail

4. Educational and Training Purposes

Section titled “4. Educational and Training Purposes”

For learning about agent development:

  • Progressive disclosure - Skills build on each other logically
  • Practical examples - Python pseudocode demonstrates concepts
  • Platform-agnostic - Learn principles, not vendor lock-in
  • Open source - Study, modify, and contribute

Daily Workflow Examples

Section titled “Daily Workflow Examples”

Best Practices

Section titled “Best Practices”

Design Philosophy

Section titled “Design Philosophy”

The collection follows three key principles:

1. Progressive Disclosure

Each skill is structured for efficient context use. At startup, agents load only skill names and descriptions. Full content loads only when a skill is activated for relevant tasks.

2. Platform Agnosticism

These skills focus on transferable principles rather than vendor-specific implementations. The patterns work across Claude Code, Cursor, and any agent platform that supports skills or allows custom instructions.

3. Conceptual Foundation with Practical Examples

Scripts and examples demonstrate concepts using Python pseudocode that works across environments without requiring specific dependency installations.

Why Agent Skills?

Section titled “Why Agent Skills?”

vs. Custom Rules:

  • Progressive disclosure reduces initial context cost
  • Community contributions expand coverage

vs. Framework Documentation:

  • Focuses on principles, not implementation details
  • Transferable across platforms
  • Practical orientation for production systems

Troubleshooting and FAQ

Section titled “Troubleshooting and FAQ”

Common Questions

Section titled “Common Questions”

Q: Do these skills work with any LLM? A: Yes, the principles are LLM-agnostic. Examples use Python pseudocode that can be adapted to any environment.

Q: How do I know which skill to use? A: Start with fundamentals, then move to architectural skills for design decisions, and operational skills for optimization.

Q: Can I contribute new skills? A: Absolutely! Follow the template structure and submit pull requests. Community contributions are welcome.

Q: Are there costs associated with using these skills? A: No, the repository is MIT licensed. However, the LLMs you use with these skills may have associated costs.

Q: How do skills handle context limits? A: Progressive disclosure means only relevant content loads. Each skill is designed to stay under 500 lines.

Troubleshooting

Section titled “Troubleshooting”

Skills not loading:

  • Ensure skill folder structure is correct
  • Check that SKILL.md exists in skill directory
  • Verify file permissions

Poor agent performance:

  • Review context-degradation skill for diagnostic patterns
  • Check if context window is being exceeded
  • Evaluate information signal-to-noise ratio

Multi-agent coordination issues:

  • Review multi-agent-patterns skill
  • Check message passing protocols
  • Verify shared memory access patterns

  • Examples: X-to-Book System example
  • Agent Skills Specification: Follow repository for updates

Conclusion

Section titled “Conclusion”

Context engineering is becoming as fundamental to AI development as software engineering principles are to traditional development. Agent Skills for Context Engineering provides a structured, open, and platform-agnostic foundation for mastering this critical discipline.

Whether you’re building your first agent or optimizing production multi-agent systems, these skills offer the conceptual foundation and practical guidance needed for success. The progressive disclosure design means you can start small and expand as needed, while the platform-agnostic approach ensures your learning transfers across tools and frameworks.

The AI agent ecosystem is maturing rapidly, and context engineering will be a key differentiator between agents that work and agents that work well. Start with the fundamentals, understand degradation patterns, and build systems that manage context effectively.

Explore the full collection at Agent Skills for Context Engineering and join the community building better agent systems.

MCPCAN: Centralized MCP Service Management Platform

Dec 24, 2025
Vibe Sparking

MCPCAN: Centralized MCP Service Management Platform

Section titled “MCPCAN: Centralized MCP Service Management Platform”

As the Model Context Protocol (MCP) ecosystem continues to expand, managing multiple MCP services across development and production environments has become increasingly complex. MCPCAN emerges as a comprehensive solution - a centralized management platform that deploys MCP services using containerized approaches while providing robust security, monitoring, and protocol conversion capabilities.

What is MCPCAN?

Section titled “What is MCPCAN?”

MCPCAN is an open-source, Kubernetes-native platform designed for DevOps teams to manage the full lifecycle of MCP services. It addresses critical challenges in MCP deployment:

  • Configuration Conflicts: Container isolation eliminates system-level conflicts
  • Security Vulnerabilities: Built-in token verification and permission management
  • Deployment Complexity: One-click deployment with Helm charts
  • Protocol Fragmentation: Seamless conversion between SSE, STDIO, and STREAMABLEHTTP

Core Features

Section titled “Core Features”

1. Unified Management Dashboard

Section titled “1. Unified Management Dashboard”

The Vue.js-powered web interface provides centralized control over all MCP service instances:

  • Visual service configuration management
  • Real-time status monitoring
  • Batch operations support
  • Service lifecycle control (start/stop/restart)

2. Multi-Protocol Support

Section titled “2. Multi-Protocol Support”

MCPCAN supports three primary MCP access protocols:

ProtocolUse CaseCharacteristics
SSEReal-time streamingServer-Sent Events for continuous updates
STDIOLocal integrationStandard input/output for CLI tools
STREAMABLEHTTPWeb applicationsHTTP-based streaming with broad compatibility

The platform handles protocol conversion automatically, allowing services written for one protocol to be accessed via another.

3. Security Authentication System

Section titled “3. Security Authentication System”

Security is built into MCPCAN’s core architecture:

  • Token Verification: Every MCP service request is validated
  • Identity Authentication: User-level access control
  • Permission Management: Role-based service access
  • Audit Logging: Complete request tracking

4. Container-Based Deployment

Section titled “4. Container-Based Deployment”

Each MCP service runs in its own isolated container:

Benefits include:

  • Resource isolation and limits
  • Independent scaling
  • Easy rollback and versioning
  • Consistent environments

5. Real-Time Monitoring

Section titled “5. Real-Time Monitoring”

Comprehensive observability features:

  • Service health dashboards
  • Performance metrics collection
  • Resource utilization tracking
  • Alert configuration

Architecture Overview

Section titled “Architecture Overview”

MCPCAN follows a microservices architecture built on Kubernetes:

Technology Stack

Section titled “Technology Stack”

Frontend:

  • Vue.js 3.5+ with Composition API
  • TypeScript for type safety
  • Pinia for state management
  • Element Plus UI components
  • Vite build tooling

Backend:

  • Go 1.24.2+ for high performance
  • Gin web framework
  • gRPC for internal communication
  • MySQL for persistent storage
  • Redis for caching and sessions

Installation Guide

Section titled “Installation Guide”

Quick Installation (Recommended)

Section titled “Quick Installation (Recommended)”

For rapid deployment with automated setup:

This automatically installs:

  • k3s (lightweight Kubernetes)
  • ingress-nginx
  • Helm 3
  • MCPCAN components

Custom Installation

Section titled “Custom Installation”

For existing Kubernetes clusters or custom configurations:

Configuration Options

Section titled “Configuration Options”

Key configuration parameters:

ParameterDescriptionDefault
domainPlatform access domainlocalhost
tls.enabledEnable HTTPSfalse
mysql.storageSizeDatabase storage10Gi
redis.enabledEnable Redis cachingtrue

Usage Scenarios

Section titled “Usage Scenarios”

Scenario 1: Enterprise MCP Gateway

Section titled “Scenario 1: Enterprise MCP Gateway”

Deploy MCPCAN as a centralized gateway for all AI assistant tools:

  1. Register MCP services through the marketplace
  2. Configure access tokens for each team
  3. Monitor usage and performance
  4. Scale services based on demand

Scenario 2: Development Team Sandbox

Section titled “Scenario 2: Development Team Sandbox”

Provide isolated MCP environments for developers:

  • Each developer gets dedicated service instances
  • Shared service pool for common tools
  • Development/staging/production separation

Scenario 3: Multi-Tenant Platform

Section titled “Scenario 3: Multi-Tenant Platform”

Operate MCP services for multiple clients:

  • Tenant isolation through namespaces
  • Per-tenant resource quotas
  • Separate billing and monitoring

Best Practices

Section titled “Best Practices”

Security Hardening

Section titled “Security Hardening”
  1. Enable TLS: Always use HTTPS in production
  2. Rotate Tokens: Implement regular token rotation
  3. Network Policies: Restrict inter-service communication
  4. Audit Everything: Enable comprehensive logging

Performance Optimization

Section titled “Performance Optimization”
  1. Resource Limits: Set appropriate CPU/memory limits
  2. Horizontal Scaling: Use HPA for auto-scaling
  3. Caching: Leverage Redis for frequent requests
  4. Connection Pooling: Optimize database connections

Operational Excellence

Section titled “Operational Excellence”
  1. GitOps: Store configurations in Git
  2. Monitoring: Set up alerts for critical metrics
  3. Backup: Regular database backups
  4. Documentation: Maintain runbooks

iOS App Store Submission: Complete Guide from Development to Review

Dec 24, 2025
Vibe Sparking

iOS App Store Submission: Complete Guide from Development to Review

Section titled “iOS App Store Submission: Complete Guide from Development to Review”

Submitting an iOS app to the App Store can feel overwhelming for first-time developers. This guide walks you through the entire process, using our MoneyMind app as a real-world example. Whether you’re building with Flutter, SwiftUI, or UIKit, these steps apply to all iOS app submissions.

Overview

Section titled “Overview”

The App Store submission process involves several key stages:

  1. App Preparation - Icon, assets, and build configuration
  2. Certificates & Provisioning - Apple Distribution certificate setup
  3. App Store Connect Setup - App information, pricing, and screenshots
  4. Build Upload - Archive and upload via Xcode
  5. Review Submission - Final checklist and submission

Let’s dive into each step.

Step 1: App Icon Creation

Section titled “Step 1: App Icon Creation”

Your app icon is the first impression users get. Apple has strict requirements:

Icon Specifications

Section titled “Icon Specifications”
  • Size: 1024 × 1024 pixels
  • Format: PNG without transparency
  • Shape: Square (iOS automatically applies corner radius)
  • Safe Zone: Keep critical elements within 600-700px centered area

Generating Icons with AI

Section titled “Generating Icons with AI”

Modern AI tools like ChatGPT and Gemini can help design app icons:

  1. Describe your app’s purpose and brand identity
  2. Request multiple variations
  3. Iterate on the best concepts
  4. Export at 1024×1024px without transparency

Flutter Icon Configuration

Section titled “Flutter Icon Configuration”

For Flutter projects, use flutter_launcher_icons:

Run the icon generator:

Step 2: Apple Distribution Certificate

Section titled “Step 2: Apple Distribution Certificate”

You need an Apple Distribution certificate to submit apps to the App Store.

Certificate Types

Section titled “Certificate Types”
Certificate TypePurposeRecommended
Apple DistributionApp Store, TestFlight, Ad Hoc✅ Yes
iOS DistributionLegacy - being deprecated❌ No
Mac App DistributionMac App Store onlyMac only

Creating a Distribution Certificate

Section titled “Creating a Distribution Certificate”
  1. Open Keychain Access on your Mac
  2. Select Keychain Access > Certificate Assistant > Request a Certificate from a Certificate Authority
  3. Enter your email and select “Saved to disk”
  4. Go to Apple Developer Portal
  5. Navigate to Certificates, Identifiers & Profiles
  6. Click + to create new certificate
  7. Select Apple Distribution
  8. Upload your Certificate Signing Request (CSR)
  9. Download and double-click to install

Pro Tip: Xcode Automatic Signing

Section titled “Pro Tip: Xcode Automatic Signing”

For simpler projects, enable automatic signing in Xcode:

  1. Open your project in Xcode
  2. Select your target
  3. Go to Signing & Capabilities
  4. Check Automatically manage signing
  5. Select your team

Step 3: Build and Upload to App Store Connect

Section titled “Step 3: Build and Upload to App Store Connect”

Archive Your App

Section titled “Archive Your App”
  1. In Xcode, select Product > Archive
  2. Wait for the build to complete
  3. The Organizer window opens automatically

Upload to App Store Connect

Section titled “Upload to App Store Connect”
  1. In the Organizer, select your archive
  2. Click Distribute App
  3. Select App Store Connect
  4. Choose Upload
  5. Follow the prompts

Build Processing

Section titled “Build Processing”

After uploading:

  • Apple processes your build (5-30 minutes)
  • You’ll receive an email when processing completes
  • Check for any issues in App Store Connect

Important: Check your email regularly! Apple may flag issues that prevent your build from appearing in App Store Connect.

Step 4: App Store Connect Configuration

Section titled “Step 4: App Store Connect Configuration”

App Information

  • Rejection Response: Typically within 24 hours of resubmission

Common Rejection Reasons & Solutions

Section titled “Common Rejection Reasons & Solutions”

1. Guideline 2.1 - App Completeness

Section titled “1. Guideline 2.1 - App Completeness”

Issue: App crashes, has placeholder content, or incomplete features.

Solution: Thoroughly test before submission. Remove any TODO or placeholder text.

2. Guideline 2.3 - Accurate Metadata

Section titled “2. Guideline 2.3 - Accurate Metadata”

Issue: Screenshots don’t match actual app, misleading descriptions.

Solution: Update screenshots after every major UI change.

3. Guideline 5.1.1 - Data Collection and Storage

Section titled “3. Guideline 5.1.1 - Data Collection and Storage”

Issue: Missing privacy policy or improper data handling disclosure.

Solution: Create comprehensive privacy policy, declare all data collection in App Store Connect.

4. Guideline 4.2 - Minimum Functionality

Section titled “4. Guideline 4.2 - Minimum Functionality”

Issue: App is too simple or doesn’t provide enough value.

Solution: Ensure your app provides meaningful functionality beyond what a website could offer.

Section titled “1. Test on Real Devices”

  • Multiple iPhone models
  • iPads (if universal app)
  • Oldest supported iOS version

Section titled “2. Monitor Email”

  • Build processing issues
  • Review status updates
  • Rejection reasons
  • App approval notifications

Section titled “3. Respond Quickly to Rejections”

  • Address all points raised
  • Ask for clarification if needed

Section titled “4. Keep TestFlight Active”

Use TestFlight for:

  • Beta testing before submission
  • Quick iteration on fixes
  • User feedback collection

5. Plan for Review Time

Section titled “5. Plan for Review Time”

Don’t submit at the last minute:

  • Allow 1-2 weeks buffer for reviews
  • Account for potential rejections
  • Holiday periods may have longer queues

Conclusion

Section titled “Conclusion”

Submitting to the App Store requires attention to detail and patience. By following this guide and preparing thoroughly, you can navigate the process smoothly and get your app into users’ hands.

Key takeaways:

  1. Prepare assets early - Icon, screenshots, and metadata take time
  2. Test thoroughly - Real device testing prevents rejections
  3. Read guidelines - Apple’s guidelines evolve; stay updated
  4. Be responsive - Quick responses to Apple expedite reviews

Google Code Wiki: AI-Powered Documentation That Evolves With Your Code

Dec 23, 2025
Vibe Sparking

Google Code Wiki: AI-Powered Documentation That Evolves With Your Code

Section titled “Google Code Wiki: AI-Powered Documentation That Evolves With Your Code”

In November 2025, Google introduced Code Wiki, a revolutionary platform that addresses one of software development’s most persistent challenges: keeping documentation synchronized with code. Powered by Gemini AI, Code Wiki automatically generates and maintains comprehensive, always-up-to-date documentation for any code repository.

What is Google Code Wiki?

Section titled “What is Google Code Wiki?”

Code Wiki is a new platform designed for the agentic era of software development. It maintains a continuously updated, structured wiki for code repositories, automatically regenerating documentation after every code change.

“A new perspective on development for the agentic era. Gemini-generated documentation, always up-to-date.”

The Documentation Problem

Section titled “The Documentation Problem”

Reading and understanding existing code is one of the biggest, most expensive bottlenecks in software development. Traditional documentation:

  • Gets outdated quickly - Code changes faster than docs can be updated
  • Lacks context - Static docs don’t explain relationships between components
  • Requires manual effort - Engineers spend time writing docs instead of coding
  • Becomes inconsistent - Different authors, different styles, incomplete coverage

Code Wiki solves these problems through automated, AI-powered documentation generation.

Core Features & Highlights

Section titled “Core Features & Highlights”

1. Automatic Documentation Generation

Section titled “1. Automatic Documentation Generation”

Code Wiki scans entire repositories and generates structured documentation automatically:

  • Full codebase analysis - Understands all files, functions, and relationships
  • Regeneration on every commit - Docs update automatically with each change
  • Architecture diagrams - Visual representations generated and kept current
  • Class and sequence diagrams - Technical visualizations for complex systems

2. Gemini-Powered Chat Interface

Section titled “2. Gemini-Powered Chat Interface”

Each Code Wiki page includes an intelligent chat agent:

  • Context-aware Q&A - Ask specific questions about YOUR codebase
  • Full wiki knowledge - Chat uses the complete, current documentation as context
  • Direct code links - Answers include hyperlinks to relevant source files
  • Natural language queries - Ask questions in plain English

Example interactions:

  • “How does the authentication module work?”
  • “What functions call the database connection pool?”
  • “Explain the data flow in the payment processing system”

3. Hyperlinked Navigation

Section titled “3. Hyperlinked Navigation”

Every documentation element connects directly to source code:

  • Symbol linking - Click any function, class, or variable to see its definition
  • Cross-references - Navigate between related concepts seamlessly
  • File locations - Know exactly where code lives
  • Definition chains - Trace from high-level concepts to implementation details

4. Powered by NotebookLM

Section titled “4. Powered by NotebookLM”

Code Wiki integrates with Google’s NotebookLM for enhanced documentation:

  • Video explanations - Auto-generated video walkthroughs of codebases
  • Interactive presentations - Architecture overviews with multimedia
  • Audio summaries - Listen to code explanations (coming soon)

Prerequisites & Getting Started

Section titled “Prerequisites & Getting Started”

Accessing Code Wiki

Section titled “Accessing Code Wiki”

Public Preview (Available Now):

  1. Visit codewiki.google
  2. Search for any public open-source repository
  3. Code Wiki generates documentation automatically

Supported Repositories:

  • GitHub public repositories
  • GitLab public projects
  • Bitbucket public repos

Featured Repositories

Section titled “Featured Repositories”

Code Wiki showcases documentation for popular projects:
