Gemini CLI Extension (Coming Soon)

Section titled “Gemini CLI Extension (Coming Soon)”

For private repositories, Google is developing a Gemini CLI extension:

  • Local deployment - Keep sensitive code on your infrastructure
  • Enterprise security - Meets compliance requirements
  • Legacy codebase support - Perfect for undocumented systems
  • Join the waitlist at codewiki.google

Recommended Use Cases

Section titled “Recommended Use Cases”

1. Onboarding New Team Members

Section titled “1. Onboarding New Team Members”

Code Wiki dramatically accelerates developer onboarding:

Before Code Wiki:

  • 2-4 weeks to understand codebase structure
  • Constant questions to senior developers
  • Reading outdated documentation
  • Trial-and-error exploration

With Code Wiki:

  • Understand system architecture in minutes
  • Ask specific questions, get accurate answers
  • Self-service exploration with chat assistant
  • Meaningful contributions on day one

2. Understanding Legacy Codebases

Section titled “2. Understanding Legacy Codebases”

For teams inheriting undocumented systems:

  • Automatic documentation - Generate docs for any codebase
  • Architecture discovery - See how components interact
  • Dependency mapping - Understand what connects to what
  • Knowledge preservation - Capture institutional knowledge

3. Code Reviews and Audits

Section titled “3. Code Reviews and Audits”

Streamline review processes:

  • Quick context - Reviewers understand changes faster
  • Impact analysis - See what code connects to modified areas
  • Consistent understanding - Everyone reads the same docs
  • Security audits - Faster codebase comprehension

4. Open Source Exploration

Section titled “4. Open Source Exploration”

Evaluate and learn from open source projects:

  • Rapid evaluation - Understand projects before adopting
  • Learning tool - See how major projects are structured
  • Contribution prep - Understand codebase before contributing
  • Pattern discovery - Learn architectural approaches

Best Practices

Section titled “Best Practices”

Maximizing Code Wiki Value

Section titled “Maximizing Code Wiki Value”
  1. Use specific questions - “How does X work?” beats “Tell me about the code”
  2. Follow hyperlinks - Navigate from docs to code for verification
  3. Refresh regularly - Check for updated docs after team commits
  4. Combine with IDE - Keep Code Wiki open alongside your editor

For Team Leads

Section titled “For Team Leads”
  1. Share wiki links - Point team members to relevant sections
  2. Standardize onboarding - Include Code Wiki in new hire checklist

vs. Manual Documentation:

  • Always current
  • Consistent formatting
  • Complete coverage

  • Cross-file relationships
  • Visual diagrams

FAQ & Troubleshooting

Section titled “FAQ & Troubleshooting”

Frequently Asked Questions

Section titled “Frequently Asked Questions”

Q: Is Code Wiki free? A: Public preview for open-source repos is free. Private repo pricing TBD.

Q: How quickly does documentation update? A: Documentation regenerates after each commit, typically within minutes.

Q: Can I customize the generated documentation? A: Currently documentation is fully automated. Custom templates may come later.

Q: Does Code Wiki support all programming languages? A: Gemini AI supports most popular languages. Quality may vary for niche languages.

Q: Is my code sent to Google’s servers? A: For public repos, yes. The CLI extension for private repos will enable local processing.

Q: Can I export the documentation? A: Export features are on the roadmap. Currently, documentation lives on codewiki.google.

Troubleshooting

Section titled “Troubleshooting”

Documentation not appearing:

  • Verify the repository is public
  • Check that the repo URL is correct
  • Wait a few minutes for initial generation

Chat not responding:

  • Refresh the page
  • Try a more specific question
  • Check your network connection

Diagrams missing:

  • Complex repos may take longer to process
  • Some architectural patterns may not visualize well
  • Check back after a few minutes

Reference Links

Section titled “Reference Links”
  • Official Site: codewiki.google
  • Google Developers Blog: Introducing Code Wiki
  • Gemini CLI Waitlist: Available at codewiki.google
  • NotebookLM: notebooklm.google

Conclusion

Section titled “Conclusion”

Google Code Wiki represents a fundamental shift in how we approach code documentation. By leveraging Gemini AI to automatically generate and maintain comprehensive, always-current documentation, Code Wiki eliminates one of software development’s most persistent pain points.

For open-source projects, the public preview is available now. For enterprise teams with private codebases, the upcoming Gemini CLI extension promises the same benefits with local deployment and security compliance.

Whether you’re onboarding new developers, exploring unfamiliar codebases, or simply wanting to understand how your own code works, Code Wiki provides an intelligent, always-updated companion for your development journey.

Try Code Wiki today at codewiki.google and experience the future of code documentation.

Auto-Claude: Autonomous Multi-Session AI Coding That 10x Your Development Output

Dec 22, 2025
Vibe Sparking

Introduction

Section titled “Introduction”

Auto-Claude is a revolutionary desktop application created by AndyMik90 that transforms how developers interact with AI coding assistants. Unlike traditional single-session AI coding tools, Auto-Claude enables you to run up to 12 parallel Claude Code terminals simultaneously, each working on different tasks while maintaining complete isolation through git worktrees.

Whether you’re a “vibe coder” just getting started or an experienced developer managing complex projects, Auto-Claude meets you where you are with autonomous agents that plan, code, and validate for you.

Key Highlights

Section titled “Key Highlights”
  • 10x Development Output: Run multiple builds simultaneously while maintaining code quality
  • 12 Parallel Agent Terminals: Clean layout with smart naming and one-click context injection
  • Git Worktree Isolation: All work happens safely without disturbing your main branch
  • Self-Validating QA: Built-in agents check their own work before you review
  • Cross-Session Memory: Agents remember insights across sessions using FalkorDB graph database
  • AI Merge Resolution: Intelligent conflict resolution when merging back to main
  • Cross-Platform: Desktop app runs on Mac, Windows, and Linux

Prerequisites

Section titled “Prerequisites”

Before installing Auto-Claude, ensure you have the following components:

RequirementVersionPurpose
Node.js18+Desktop UI runtime
Python3.10+Backend agent execution
Docker DesktopLatestMemory Layer (FalkorDB)
Claude Code CLILatestAI coding engine
Claude SubscriptionPro or MaxRequired for Claude Code access
Git Repository-Worktree isolation

Git Initialization

Section titled “Git Initialization”

Auto-Claude requires a git repository to create isolated worktrees for safe parallel development:

Git worktrees allow you to work on multiple features simultaneously without conflicts, keeping your main branch clean until you’re ready to merge.

Windows Users

Section titled “Windows Users”

  1. Download Visual Studio Build Tools 2022
  2. Select “Desktop development with C++” workload
  3. Add “MSVC v143 - VS 2022 C++ x64/x86 Spectre-mitigated libs”
  4. Restart terminal and run npm install again

Core Features

Section titled “Core Features”

1. Kanban Board Interface

Section titled “1. Kanban Board Interface”

Plan tasks and let AI handle planning, coding, and validation in a visual interface. Track progress from “Planning” to “Done” while agents work autonomously.

2. Agent Terminals

Section titled “2. Agent Terminals”

Spawn up to 12 AI-powered terminals for hands-on coding:

  • Inject task context with a click
  • Reference files from your project
  • Work rapidly across multiple sessions
  • Connect multiple Claude Code subscriptions for teams

3. Three-Phase Agent Pipeline

Section titled “3. Three-Phase Agent Pipeline”

Phase 1: Spec Creation (3-8 phases)

  • Discovery — Analyzes project structure and tech stack
  • Requirements — Gathers requirements through interactive conversation
  • Research — Validates external integrations against real documentation
  • Context Discovery — Finds relevant files in your codebase
  • Spec Writer — Creates comprehensive specification document
  • Spec Critic — Self-critiques using extended thinking
  • Planner — Breaks work into subtasks with dependencies
  • Validation — Ensures all outputs are valid

Phase 2: Implementation

  • Planner Agent creates subtask-based implementation plan
  • Coder Agent implements subtasks one-by-one with verification
  • QA Reviewer validates all acceptance criteria
  • QA Fixer fixes issues in a self-healing loop (up to 50 iterations)

Phase 3: Merge

  • Conflict Detection identifies modified files
  • 3-Tier Resolution: Git auto-merge → Conflict-only AI → Full-file AI
  • Parallel Merge for multiple files simultaneously
  • Staged for Review before finalizing

4. Memory Layer Architecture

Section titled “4. Memory Layer Architecture”

The Memory Layer combines graph nodes with semantic search:

SetupLLMEmbeddingsNotes
OpenAIOpenAIOpenAISimplest - single API key
Anthropic + VoyageAnthropicVoyage AIHigh quality
Google AIGeminiGoogleFast inference
OllamaOllamaOllamaFully offline
AzureAzure OpenAIAzure OpenAIEnterprise

5. Security Model

Section titled “5. Security Model”

Three-layer defense keeps your code safe:

  • OS Sandbox: Bash commands run in isolation
  • Filesystem Restrictions: Operations limited to project directory
  • Command Allowlist: Only approved commands based on your project’s stack

  • Improving test coverage

Scenario 4: Team Collaboration

Section titled “Scenario 4: Team Collaboration”

Power users can connect multiple Claude Code subscriptions:

  • Each team member runs their own set of agents
  • Shared Memory Layer preserves project context
  • AI handles merge conflicts across branches

Best Practices

Section titled “Best Practices”

  1. Start with Clear Specifications: Provide detailed task descriptions for better agent performance

  2. Use Git Worktrees: Let Auto-Claude manage isolation - never work directly on main during builds

  3. Review QA Reports: Check the self-validation results before accepting changes

  4. Leverage Memory Layer: Enable FalkorDB for better context across sessions

  5. Batch Similar Tasks: Group related work to maximize parallel efficiency

  6. Monitor Resource Usage: 12 parallel agents can be resource-intensive - adjust based on your hardware

Precautions and FAQ

Section titled “Precautions and FAQ”

Precautions

Section titled “Precautions”
  1. Claude Subscription Required: You need Claude Pro or Max for Claude Code access
  2. Resource Intensive: Running 12 parallel agents requires significant CPU/RAM
  3. Docker Dependency: Memory Layer requires Docker Desktop running
  4. AGPL-3.0 License: Commercial use requires open-sourcing your modifications

FAQ

Section titled “FAQ”

Q: How is Auto-Claude different from regular Claude Code? A: Auto-Claude wraps Claude Code with parallel execution, git worktree isolation, self-validating QA, and cross-session memory. It’s a productivity multiplier, not a replacement.

Q: Can I use this with my existing project? A: Yes! Just ensure your project is a git repository. Auto-Claude creates isolated worktrees without modifying your main branch.

Q: How many agents should I run? A: Start with 2-4 and scale up based on your hardware. Each agent consumes Claude Code API credits separately.

Q: Does it work offline? A: The Memory Layer supports Ollama for fully offline operation, but Claude Code requires internet connectivity.

Q: What happens if an agent gets stuck? A: The QA Fixer runs up to 50 iterations in a self-healing loop. If it still fails, you can review and intervene manually.

Enabling Claude Code to Work More Autonomously: Complete Guide to VS Code Extension, Checkpoints & Agent SDK

Dec 22, 2025
Vibe Sparking

Introduction

Section titled “Introduction”

Anthropic has released several major upgrades to Claude Code that fundamentally transform how developers interact with AI-powered development tools. These updates include a native VS Code extension, version 2.0 of the terminal interface, and most notably, checkpoints for autonomous operation. Powered by Claude Sonnet 4.5, Claude Code now handles longer, more complex development tasks with unprecedented confidence and control.

This article provides a comprehensive guide to these new autonomy features, covering installation, configuration, best practices, and real-world workflow examples.

Key Features and Highlights

Section titled “Key Features and Highlights”

1. Native VS Code Extension (Beta)

Section titled “1. Native VS Code Extension (Beta)”

The native VS Code extension brings Claude Code directly into your IDE with several powerful capabilities:

  • Real-time Change Visualization: See Claude’s changes in real-time through a dedicated sidebar panel with inline diffs
  • Graphical Experience: A richer, more visual Claude Code experience for developers who prefer IDEs over terminals
  • Seamless Integration: Works within your existing VS Code workflow without context switching

Installation: Download from the VS Code Extension Marketplace

2. Enhanced Terminal Experience (v2.0)

Section titled “2. Enhanced Terminal Experience (v2.0)”

The refreshed terminal interface includes:

  • Improved Status Visibility: Better visual feedback on Claude’s current operations
  • Searchable Prompt History: Use Ctrl+r to search and reuse previous prompts
  • Streamlined UX: Easier navigation and command execution

3. Checkpoints System

Section titled “3. Checkpoints System”

The checkpoint system is a game-changer for autonomous development:

  • Automatic State Saving: Automatically saves your code state before each change
  • Instant Rewind: Tap Esc twice or use /rewind command to return to previous versions
  • Selective Restoration: Choose to restore code, conversation, or both
  • Multi-level Undo: Not just one level—checkpoints are kept for each change

Best Practice: Use checkpoints in combination with version control (git) for maximum safety.

4. Subagents for Parallel Development

Section titled “4. Subagents for Parallel Development”

Subagents delegate specialized tasks, enabling parallel development workflows:

5. Hooks for Automated Workflows

Section titled “5. Hooks for Automated Workflows”

Hooks trigger actions at specific points in the development lifecycle:

  • PostToolUse: Run tests after code changes
  • PreToolUse: Lint before commits
  • SessionStart/End: Initialize or cleanup resources
  • UserPromptSubmit: Validate or transform user input

6. Background Tasks

Section titled “6. Background Tasks”

Keep long-running processes active without blocking progress:

  • Dev servers running continuously
  • Build watchers monitoring changes
  • Database migrations running in background
  • Compilation tasks executing asynchronously

  • Python: Version 3.10 or higher (for Python SDK)
  • Operating System: macOS, Linux, or Windows with WSL

Section titled “Scenario 1: Complex Refactoring”

  2. Spawn subagents for different modules

Precautions and FAQ

Section titled “Precautions and FAQ”

Safety Considerations

Section titled “Safety Considerations”

  1. Checkpoints vs Git: Checkpoints only track Claude’s edits, not user edits or bash commands. Always use git for version control.

  2. Subagent Permissions: Be careful about which tools you grant to subagents. Use principle of least privilege.

  3. Background Tasks: Monitor background tasks to prevent resource exhaustion.

Frequently Asked Questions

Section titled “Frequently Asked Questions”

Q: Can I use checkpoints without git? A: Yes, but it’s not recommended. Checkpoints supplement, not replace, version control.

Q: How many subagents can run in parallel? A: There’s no hard limit, but resource constraints apply. Start with 2-3 and scale based on your system.

Q: Do hooks slow down development? A: Minimal overhead. Hooks run asynchronously where possible.

Q: Can I use Claude Code with local models? A: The Agent SDK supports Bedrock, Vertex AI, and Foundry. Local model support depends on provider compatibility.

Troubleshooting

Section titled “Troubleshooting”
IssueSolution

Subagent timeoutIncrease timeout in options or simplify task
Hook not triggeringVerify matcher regex matches tool name
API key invalidRegenerate key from Console

  • GitHub Copilot: Best for inline code suggestions

Conclusion

Section titled “Conclusion”

Claude Code’s autonomy upgrades represent a significant leap in AI-assisted development. The combination of checkpoints, subagents, hooks, and background tasks creates a development environment where you can confidently delegate complex tasks while maintaining full control. Whether you’re refactoring a legacy codebase, building new features, or exploring experimental approaches, these tools provide the safety net and parallel processing power to work more efficiently than ever before.

Start with the VS Code extension for a gentler learning curve, then graduate to the Agent SDK for building production-ready autonomous agents tailored to your specific workflows.

Fabric: The Open-Source Framework for Augmenting Humans Using AI

Dec 22, 2025
Vibe Sparking

Fabric: The Open-Source Framework for Augmenting Humans Using AI

Section titled “Fabric: The Open-Source Framework for Augmenting Humans Using AI”

In the rapidly evolving landscape of AI tools, Fabric stands out as a revolutionary open-source framework designed to bridge the gap between AI capabilities and human integration. Created by security researcher and AI enthusiast Daniel Miessler, Fabric addresses a fundamental problem: AI doesn’t have a capabilities problem—it has an integration problem.

What is Fabric?

Section titled “What is Fabric?”

Fabric is an open-source framework that organizes and manages AI prompts—called Patterns—in a modular, reusable system. Unlike scattered prompts across various tools and platforms, Fabric provides a centralized, command-line-first approach to collecting, organizing, and executing AI solutions.

The Philosophy Behind Fabric

Section titled “The Philosophy Behind Fabric”

“AI isn’t a thing; it’s a magnifier of a thing. And that thing is human creativity.”

Fabric’s philosophy centers on breaking complex problems into manageable components and applying AI to each piece systematically. This approach transforms AI from a mysterious black box into a practical, everyday tool.

Key Features and Highlights

Section titled “Key Features and Highlights”

1. Pattern-Based Architecture

Section titled “1. Pattern-Based Architecture”

Patterns are the core building blocks of Fabric. Each Pattern is a carefully crafted prompt designed for a specific real-world task:

  • extract_wisdom: Extract key insights from YouTube videos and podcasts
  • summarize: Create concise summaries of any content
  • analyze_claims: Evaluate claims for accuracy and validity
  • write_essay: Generate essays in your own voice
  • create_coding_feature: Generate code features with context
  • improve_writing: Enhance writing quality and clarity

With over 150+ built-in Patterns, Fabric covers diverse use cases from content creation to code analysis.

2. Multi-Model Support

Section titled “2. Multi-Model Support”

Fabric supports an impressive array of AI providers:

  • OpenAI (GPT-4, GPT-4o, o1, o3)
  • Anthropic (Claude 4, Claude 4.5 Opus)
  • Google (Gemini)
  • Local models via Ollama
  • Azure OpenAI
  • Amazon Bedrock
  • Perplexity AI
  • Venice AI (privacy-focused)
  • Together AI
  • And many more…

3. Seamless CLI Integration

Section titled “3. Seamless CLI Integration”

Fabric is built for the command line, making it perfect for developers and power users:

4. Context and Session Management

Section titled “4. Context and Session Management”

Fabric supports persistent contexts and sessions:

  • Contexts: Pre-created background information added to all queries
  • Sessions: Maintain conversation history across multiple interactions
  • Variables: Dynamic pattern customization with {{variable}} syntax

5. REST API Server

Section titled “5. REST API Server”

Fabric includes a built-in REST API server for integration with other applications:

Features include:

  • Chat completions with streaming
  • Pattern management (CRUD operations)
  • YouTube transcript extraction
  • Swagger/OpenAPI documentation

6. Web Interface

Section titled “6. Web Interface”

A GUI alternative to the CLI is available for those who prefer visual interfaces, providing access to all Fabric functionality through a web browser.

Prerequisites

Section titled “Prerequisites”

Before installing Fabric, ensure you have:

  • Go 1.22+ (for source installation)
  • API keys for your preferred AI providers (OpenAI, Anthropic, etc.)
  • yt-dlp (optional, for YouTube transcript extraction)
  • LaTeX distribution (optional, for PDF generation with to_pdf)

FAQ

Section titled “FAQ”

Q: Is Fabric free to use? A: Yes, Fabric is MIT licensed. However, you need API keys for AI providers, which may have costs.

Q: Can I use Fabric without internet? A: Yes, with local models through Ollama.

Q: How do I contribute patterns? A: Submit a pull request to the Fabric repository with your pattern in the data/patterns directory.

Q: Does Fabric store my data? A: Fabric processes data locally. Data is sent to AI providers based on your configuration.

Q: Can I use multiple models in one workflow? A: Yes, you can chain patterns with different models using shell pipes.

Recent Updates (December 2025)

Section titled “Recent Updates (December 2025)”
  • v1.4.350: Interactive API Documentation with Swagger/OpenAPI UI
  • v1.4.338: Abacus vendor support for Chat-LLM models
  • v1.4.334: Claude Opus 4.5 model support
  • v1.4.322: Interactive HTML Concept Maps with Vis.js
  • v1.4.309: Comprehensive internationalization (9 languages)

  • Intro Videos:

    • Daniel Miessler’s Overview
  • Daniel Miessler’s Website: danielmiessler.com

Conclusion

Section titled “Conclusion”

Fabric represents a paradigm shift in how we interact with AI. By providing a structured, modular, and command-line-friendly framework, it transforms AI from an occasional tool into an integrated part of our daily workflows. Whether you’re a developer, content creator, security researcher, or knowledge worker, Fabric’s pattern-based approach offers a powerful way to augment your capabilities with AI.

The project’s active development, growing community, and extensive pattern library make it an essential tool for anyone serious about leveraging AI effectively. Start with the basic patterns, explore the community contributions, and eventually create your own—that’s the path to truly augmented human productivity.

This article was researched and written with assistance from AI tools, demonstrating the very integration that Fabric enables.
